item.title: Malcolm Gladwell on Freakonomics Radio
item.description:
If you are missing your fix of Malcolm Gladwell’s voice1, I would highly recommend this older episode of Freakonomics Radio:

The principles of deliberate practice strike me as being most useful on questions like, “How to think?” So the whole notion that you would — when you have made a decision, when you have considered a set of data or evidence and drawn some conclusion — that you would submit your process to some kind of either internal or external review. I’m trying to figure out how to do a better job the next time. That strikes me as what we need. Because, you know, one of his observations about deliberate practice is that practice becomes useless when it’s unreflective.

Gladwell discusses the misinterpretation of his interpretation of Anders Ericsson’s work in Outliers. Many people focus on the 10,000 hour rule and believe Gladwell misinterpreted Ericsson’s work. However, Gladwell’s intent with Outliers was broader:

But one is that I wanted people to move away from the notion of success as something individual. And I wanted to get people to understand that a lot of success has to do with chance, with the contribution of your culture, your generation, your family.

  1. I would also highly recommend Gladwell’s podcast Revisionist History, specifically the episodes Carlos Doesn’t Remember, Food Fight, and My Little Hundred Million. [return]

item.title: about this blog
item.description:
I finally set up my blog after thinking about it for a while. It was easy and cheap thanks to the instructions on Superfluous Sextant. On the technical side, I decided to use Hugo instead of a Python static site generator1, even though I am a big fan of Python.

I started this blog in order to write about programming, data analysis, finance2, sports, interesting articles, books I am reading, and whatever else comes to mind.3 The name of the blog (undervalued) comes from my love of researching stocks and hopefully finding undervalued companies. I am a hobbyist deep value investor and contrarian.

One of the models for this blog is Daring Fireball. I like how Gruber links to stories, offers plenty of snark, and also writes longer opinion pieces.4

Footnotes

  1. The suggestion for using Hugo also came Superfluous Sextant. [return]
  2. Usual disclaimer here… I am not a financial expert or licensed in any way to give financial advice. The opinions expressed here are solely my own and should not be taken as financial advice. Consult a professional (ideally one with fiduciary duty to you) before making financial decisions. [return]
  3. I am still undecided about political writing on here. Although more and more and more technical people are writing about political issues. I would highly recommend Jeff Atwood’s post since it kind of mirrors my thinking. [return]
  4. I have always wanted to point out how ridiculous it is that accepting a loan from your CEO is a sign of trouble when not accepting a loan was also a sign of trouble 6 months earlier. Sears has plenty of problems, but my point is that the financial press (even publications I respect like Bloomberg) often look for correlations where there are none. [return]
